description:
See the thread "Packaging." on yt-dev for more info.

This is contained within the bookmark "conda" in my repo.  To get it, do:

   hg pull -r conda http://bitbucket.org/MatthewTurk/yt/
   hg up -r conda

That will ensure you don't grab all the extra stuff I have in my repo.  You can also simply download the raw file here.

UPDATE 1: Updated as per @ngoldbaum
title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Can we preserve the information from the old install script about xcode versions?  Apple has made this decidedly non-obvious to the point where googling 'install Xcode command line tools' will give confusing, contridictory results if the user isn't on the latest OS X release.
content.html: Can we preserve the information from the old install script about xcode versions? Apple has made this decidedly non-obvious to the point where googling 'install Xcode command line tools' will give confusing, contridictory results if the user isn't on the latest OS X release.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Can we get a precise listing of packages they'll need, along with a `sudo apt-get install ..` and `sudo yum install ...` lines that they can copy/paste?
content.html: Can we get a precise listing of packages they'll need, along with a sudo apt-get install .. and sudo yum install ... lines that they can copy/paste?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Do we need to update the activate script or provide a stripped-down conda-only activate script?
content.html: Do we need to update the activate script or provide a stripped-down conda-only activate script?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Sure, do you think it can just be copy/pasted from the old one?
content.html: Sure, do you think it can just be copy/pasted from the old one?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Sure -- easy enough to put back in right?  Or do we need to update the language?
content.html: Sure -- easy enough to put back in right? Or do we need to update the language?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: I think that for the yt source install we *do* want to ship it, since it will *also* set `YT_DEST`.
content.html: I think that for the yt source install we do want to ship it, since it will also set YT_DEST.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Can we have an explicit `export PATH=...` line that they can copy/paste into their .bashrc or .bash_profile?
content.html: Can we have an explicit export PATH=... line that they can copy/paste into their .bashrc or .bash_profile?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Yup, great idea.
content.html: Yup, great idea.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: It would be cool if we could check for an up-to-date build on binstar that is appropriate for the platform.  That would obviate the need for getting the recipe and building it.
content.html: It would be cool if we could check for an up-to-date build on binstar that is appropriate for the platform. That would obviate the need for getting the recipe and building it.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: I'm not sure, I'd expect some of the dependencies are no longer necessary but I'd have to check in a VM to be certain.
content.html: I'm not sure, I'd expect some of the dependencies are no longer necessary but I'd have to check in a VM to be certain.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Good point.  Would it be sufficient to check for success/failure on a conda install, but specify the version number?  Then we'd have to update the version each time we do a new release.
content.html: Good point. Would it be sufficient to check for success/failure on a conda install, but specify the version number? Then we'd have to update the version each time we do a new release.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: I think that can be safely copy/pasted.  It will need to be updated for 10.9 once one of us installs that.
content.html: I think that can be safely copy/pasted. It will need to be updated for 10.9 once one of us installs that.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: I think that would work. Another option would be to check for a 404 on binstar.org.  I believe the package names can be constructed programatically in a straightforward way.
content.html: I think that would work. Another option would be to check for a 404 on binstar.org. I believe the package names can be constructed programatically in a straightforward way.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Right, I'm trying to say that the current activate script might be overkill. It might also be nice to have `YT_DEST` set for the binary-only install as well.
content.html: Right, I'm trying to say that the current activate script might be overkill. It might also be nice to have YT_DEST set for the binary-only install as well.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: It might be, but I think we need more experimentation before we decide that.  For the binary install, the question I have is about the ExtJS deps, and I'm not sure yet about that.  Can we try it a few places before deciding on this?
content.html: It might be, but I think we need more experimentation before we decide that. For the binary install, the question I have is about the ExtJS deps, and I'm not sure yet about that. Can we try it a few places before deciding on this?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Sure.  Good point about reason.
content.html: Sure. Good point about reason.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: As I've just now been testing something to do this, my thinking is that what we should do is instead try to migrate to having binary builds done on a frequent basis; @xarthisius has mentioned this as a possibility.  We should then just ditch any of the yt-recipes, and either do binary or source.
content.html: As I've just now been testing something to do this, my thinking is that what we should do is instead try to migrate to having binary builds done on a frequent basis; Kacper Kowalik has mentioned this as a possibility. We should then just ditch any of the yt-recipes, and either do binary or source.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: What about yt-doc and yt-supplemental?  Also should we clone yt, yt-doc, and yt-supplemental for binary installs as well?  That way these users at least have the source code in an easily accessible place.  That should also make it possible to do `bootstrap_dev` if they so wish.
content.html: What about yt-doc and yt-supplemental? Also should we clone yt, yt-doc, and yt-supplemental for binary installs as well? That way these users at least have the source code in an easily accessible place. That should also make it possible to do bootstrap_dev if they so wish.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw:
On my Mac laptop, `INST_YT_SOURCE=1` fails due to [Anaconda issue #18](https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/18).  It probably won't work until the hdf5 package is updated. I'll ask over on github if there is a workaround.

`INST_YT_SOURCE=0` produces a working yt build that passes all of the unit tests :)

I think you need to prepend all the `popd` and `pushd` calls with `log_cmd`.

One possible issue - how should users update yt?  `yt update` will only work for the source installs.  We could fix that by making `yt update` a bit more conda-aware, I think.
content.html:
On my Mac laptop, INST_YT_SOURCE=1 fails due to Anaconda issue #18. It probably won't work until the hdf5 package is updated. I'll ask over on github if there is a workaround.

INST_YT_SOURCE=0 produces a working yt build that passes all of the unit tests :)

I think you need to prepend all the popd and pushd calls with log_cmd.

One possible issue - how should users update yt? yt update will only work for the source installs. We could fix that by making yt update a bit more conda-aware, I think.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: This leaves the miniconda package behind.
content.html: This leaves the miniconda package behind.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: When I tried this the first time the download was interrupted and the miniconda file I ended up with was corrupted.  Fortunately the miniconda script includes an internal checksum but perhaps we should check the hash ourselves and bail if the download fails.
content.html: When I tried this the first time the download was interrupted and the miniconda file I ended up with was corrupted. Fortunately the miniconda script includes an internal checksum but perhaps we should check the hash ourselves and bail if the download fails.

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: $PATH is expanded by bash here and it looks a little confusing.  Can you escape it?
content.html: $PATH is expanded by bash here and it looks a little confusing. Can you escape it?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: Can you add "or .bash_profile on a Mac"?
content.html: Can you add "or .bash_profile on a Mac"?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw:
I think @scopatz had some ideas about HDF5 linking and conda and whatnot.

I'll update and modify the `popd`/`pushd` calls.

And, I'm not entirely sure the right solution for a source install inside a conda environment.  I'm fine with disabling `yt update` when a binary is installed.  We may simply want to use buildbots and have nightly builds.  @xarthisius do you think other than the comments @ngoldbaum made (which include the source issues I mentioned on the anaconda mailing list here: https://groups.google.com/a/continuum.io/d/msg/anaconda/N_NQcCcWFqo/3F0pU36bCP8J ) that we're ready to start deploying and testing?
content.html:
I think Anthony Scopatz had some ideas about HDF5 linking and conda and whatnot.

I'll update and modify the popd/pushd calls.

And, I'm not entirely sure the right solution for a source install inside a conda environment. I'm fine with disabling yt update when a binary is installed. We may simply want to use buildbots and have nightly builds. Kacper Kowalik do you think other than the comments Nathan Goldbaum made (which include the source issues I mentioned on the anaconda mailing list here: https://groups.google.com/a/continuum.io/d/msg/anaconda/N_NQcCcWFqo/3F0pU36bCP8J ) that we're ready to start deploying and testing?

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw: I still haven't preped the OSX build boxes, but on the Linux end I think we're good to go. Initial version of this script has been [integrated](http://tests.yt-project.org/job/conda-install/) for a while
content.html: I still haven't preped the OSX build boxes, but on the Linux end I think we're good to go. Initial version of this script has been integrated for a while

pullrequest.title: First draft of a new "get_yt" script based on Conda.

content.raw:
My ideas mostly amount to having a compiler and building HDF5 from scratch.  This is what I had to do for PyNE on Shining Panda.  I know this isn't helpful but I could find no other way around this.

Go to the source, young bears.
content.html:
My ideas mostly amount to having a compiler and building HDF5 from scratch. This is what I had to do for PyNE on Shining Panda. I know this isn't helpful but I could find no other way around this.

Go to the source, young bears.
